    Head U -

     The Chairman: We have 20 minutes for this discussion.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head U of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, the elected President issue was an election issue in the 1988 general election. At that time, the Government said that legislation would be in place by December that year for an elected President. Now almost 1 1/2 years have passed and there is still no news of this very important issue. In the last general election, the Government made the question of the elected President to appear to be an urgent one and the installation of an elected President was imminent. As it turned out, it was nothing but hot air. The Opposition and the people of Singapore have been misled. It was a clever election ploy on the part of the Government. There was really no urgency at all in having an elected President. Our reserves are still safe and intact and I would say that they would remain to be safe and intact as long as there are elections where the people of Singapore are free to elect candidates of their own choice. I will concede that the Opposition had been had at the last election as far as the issue of the elected President was concerned. We have been led up the garden path. We shall of course learn from that lesson and never to believe everything the PAP Government says. We have to remind the people of Singapore at the next election to beware of the PAP's election tricks.

Column: 173



    Now, we see in the budget that there is an allocation of $1.65 million to be allocated to the Elections Department to meet expenses for a possible Presidential elections. The situation has become more perplexing. We note now that the sum of $1.65 million to be set aside is not for a certain Presidential election but a possible Presidential election. What does the dictionary say of the meaning of the word "possible"? It says, "That can exist, happen or be done, or that may or may not happen". Whatever meaning is taken, the word "possible" connotes that there is an uncertainty. Therefore, Presidential election may or may not take place in the financial year 1990-91.

    The question of the elected President is of paramount importance to the people of Singapore. Our Constitution will have to be materially changed. The supremacy of our Parliament, as we know it today, will be eroded and yet the Government, if it is serious about the elected President, should tell the people of Singapore exactly when the election of the elected President will be. I would like to ask the First Deputy Prime Minister whether a Bill will be introduced in Parliament this year in regard to an elected President. If the answer is in the positive, then the Opposition would demand that there be a referendum. In this referendum, the question must be squarely put to the adult citizens of Singapore whether they want or do not want an elected President. The Government's style is said to be one of consensus. There is no better way to get a consensual response from the public than a national referendum on this very important issue. There can be no other better way.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh (Non-Constituency Member): Sir, I endorse what Mr Chiam has just said. The issue of the elected President was easily the most hotly debated issue in the 1988 general election. There was even a special TV forum with Government Ministers and Opposition party representatives taking part.

    Sir, I believe that, with hardly any exception, all of us agree that our national financial assets and the integrity of the public service should be safeguarded. But

Column: 174

there are many features in the proposal in the White Paper on the elected President which are most undesirable and completely unacceptable to many, many people. Of course, it was widely interpreted that the post of the elected President has been specially created for our Prime Minister, Mr Lee Kuan Yew, so that he could happily resign from his post as Prime Minister and still control events in Singapore.

    Our Prime Minister has said on many occasions, that he would soon step down to allow a new generation of PAP leaders to take charge of government in Singapore. But, unfortunately, for PAP's plans, the elected President issue has come into very strong widespread opposition. Thus, the implementation of the scheme has to be put aside for a while.

    Since the 1988 elections, no mention has been made of the issue of the elected President. Now we suddenly see that provision has been made in the 1990 budget for a possible Presidential election this year. Is it because the Prime Minister has confirmed that he will step down as Prime Minister this year? But he has also publicly said that he will not be the first elected President. So what are the plans ahead?

    Is the proposed post of the Senior Minister in the Cabinet merely a temporary stop gap? Otherwise, why the provision for a "possible Presidential election" in the budget? Has the time-table been pushed forward suddenly and a Presidential election will soon be held this year? Until today, Sir, the people have not been informed what Government plans really are, nor how Government intends to carry out these plans. Important issues like the elected President should not be sprung as a surprise on the people.

    To elect an elected President, amendments have to be made to the Constitution, as has already been stressed by Mr Chiam. Are there going to be amendments to the Constitution soon? Do we have enough time to discuss the matter before the Government pushes ahead with the plan?

    Another thing that comes to mind is that the present President of Singapore, Mr Wee Kim Wee, was elected to office only

Column: 175

one year ago. Does this mean that he is to be retired soon? Only after one year? What is the hurry? Whatever it may be, the Constitution has first to be amended. How is that to be done? Merely by means of a simple parliamentary majority? There was a big controversy over the issue. The PAP, let us not forget, had only 60% of popular votes in the last election. Nearly 40% of popular votes had opposed the PAP. Therefore, as already stressed by Mr Chiam, should we not first hold a referendum on the issue?

    The First Deputy Prime Minister has said that he will hold a referendum to find out whether or not the people want an elected President as envisaged in the White Paper. Is the provision of $1.65 million meant for holding a referendum? Would the First Deputy Prime Minister please explain?

    We certainly cannot hold an election before the Constitution is amended and before a referendum is held on the issue. If elections are held first, that would be putting the cart before the horse. First things must come first. Would the First Deputy Prime Minister enlighten the House and answer the points both Mr Chiam and I have raised?

     The First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Sir, Mr Chiam has made a number of inaccurate statements. So first let me put him right.

    He said that we promised to have the President elected before 30th December. I do not remember that we had made such a promise. I assume he meant 30th December, 1988. Secondly, he alleged that the elected President was an election ploy. It was not an election ploy at all. We believe that this issue was of a fundamental nature and we therefore decided that it should be put before the people so that we clearly could have the mandate to proceed with the implementation after the elections.

    Mr Chiam seems to have forgotten that it was he who in fact asked that the matter be put before the people at the 1988 elections. He held a rally at the Ang Mo Kio Sports Complex sometime in August 1988. He specifically said that the elected Presi-

Column: 176

dent should be made an issue at the coming polls. That was exactly what the PAP did. In case Mr Chiam has forgotten what he said on 7th August, 1988, he should refer to the Sunday Times, a copy of which is in my hand.

    The issue of an elected President is a very important issue and for that reason we have taken our time for people to understand the importance of this issue so that when we come to a debate on the legislation, the people are prepared for it.

    Briefly, to recapitulate, there are two objectives in the proposal. The first objective is to protect the national reserves, including those which members have in the CPF. The second objective, which is part of the first objective, is to ensure that the integrity of the civil service is protected. If the civil service's integrity is not protected, ways can be found by a profligate government to quietly raid the reserves and deplete the reserves which belong to the people, both in the Treasury as well as the CPF reserves.

    Both Dr Lee Siew-Choh and Mr Chiam asked: when would elections be held? They would like to know the time frame of the plan that we have. But, first, let me say that the question of the elected President was in fact part of the President's Address. Please refer to the President's Address and you will discover that this item is part of the agenda which we intend to fulfil in this session of Parliament. The question is timing. When do we intend to introduce legislation?

    We have taken some time to clear the more important matters of Government and, after this budget, we do intend to table before this House legislation on the elected President. It will be done before the end of this year. The Bill will be debated in Parliament and we intend to refer the Bill to a Select Committee. Thereafter, whether we have an election or not, I think it is purely one which we will decide nearer the time. Hence, the provision for a possible election in the coming year.

    Mr Chiam argues that the matter should be put before the people in a referendum. I do not believe in boiling an egg twice. It was an election issue. To quote Dr Lee

Column: 177

Siew-Choh, "the most hotly debated issue in the last election." We went out to the people to tell them that we intended to implement this proposal after the election and we were seeking the people's mandate for us to proceed. Both Dr Lee and Mr Chiam and other Opposition parties combined to campaign against the issue and they combined to deny the PAP two-thirds of the seats in Parliament. We therefore joined issues in the last election on the elected President. We, on the one hand, were seeking the people's mandate for the proposal. The Opposition parties, on the other hand, combined to try and deny the PAP a two-thirds majority in the House so that we would not be able to proceed. We won all but one seat. Is there a need for a referendum? I think the answer is quite clear.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, please allow me to make certain clarifications. I believe we have up to 1.20 pm.

    Sir, the PAP did say that the Bill would be in place by December 1988 and not the installation of the elected President by 1988. This is clearly implanted in my mind. Yes, the Bill would be ready by December 1988, and now already about 1 1/2 years have passed and we have not heard of it yet. There is a possibility that the Bill will be ready by the end of this year. There is still no certainty. This issue is of such great importance and yet the people are left with an uncertainty.

    The First Deputy Prime Minister said that it was not an election ploy. But I think the more important point is the manner in which the PAP canvassed this issue. They canvassed it as if it was a very urgent and imminent issue. I think that is the crux of the matter. The matter was of the greatest urgency and not a question of whether we have an elected President or not. The feeling of the people at that time was that it was going to happen very soon. So I think that was a ploy in that sense. We cannot say that at that election the PAP had the mandate of the people to have an elected President because, if the First Deputy Prime Minister will remember correctly, in fact this issue was canvassed, in particular by the SDP, because we felt that it was

Column: 178

such an important issue but, to the people I think the town council issue overrode this issue. In fact, the bread and butter issues as regards the town council, the falling prices of their flats, the fear of not getting their proper services and such like which overtook this very important issue. If there was any main issue at all, it was the town council issue, and not the elected President issue.

    Therefore, there is justification for the call of a referendum even at this time. We did call for a referendum at the last general election. The PAP did not respond to this very important demand. If the Government is sincere about wanting a style of consensus, I think there is no better way of a consensual agreement than a referendum. Then they would be certain that such an important issue is decided by the people. And also as Dr Lee Siew-Choh has pointed out, although the PAP has got 80 out of the 81 elected seats, in fact, in absolute number of votes, they do not command a two-thirds majority. I think that is a very important point to put across to the people. This is a very important issue and we should look at the votes rather than the number of PAP Members in this House.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Sir, the PAP has always tried to use different arguments to suit the occasion. At one time when it suited them they said elections. At another time, when it suited them they said referendum. As he already been said on another occasion, a referendum is carried out to determine whether or not the people really support any single issue. In an election there are a multitude of issues. I said the elected President issue was one of the hotly debated issues in the last election but not the only issue. Therefore, the First Deputy Prime Minister should not seize on the PAP's election victory to get away from the need to hold a referendum. In other countries, Sir, whenever there are important constitutional issues, a referendum is always being held - in Switzerland, in Australia, everywhere in fact, to decide on the single issue. But in an election, so many issues are brought in. If somebody is corrupt, there you are, that could influence the result of an election. If other issues crop in, like the town council, people can be divided as to how they should vote.

Column: 179



    Therefore, the First Deputy Prime Minister should be specific. The Presidential issue is a very important issue. If the Government has confidence of support, it should not fear to hold a referendum. Hold it and see whether or not the people support the Government. The PAP had only 60% of the popular votes. But, because of the manner the electoral districts have been arranged, it managed to gain 80 of the 81 seats. But that does not mean to say the PAP has the support of the majority of the people.

    I just want to stress that it has to hold a referendum before the Government can claim that it has the support of the people on the elected President issue. PAP leaders should not be afraid since they are so confident that the people will support them. They have stressed so very much on the need for consensus. Let them test this consensus, and we will see how many people really support the Government on this issue. If the Government should hold a referendum, well, the Government need have no fear. Even if it should lose the referendum, it still would not fall. It will still continue to be the Government. That is the whole idea of a referendum for many people. The Government is safe.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Sir, Mr Chiam See Tong was wrong to say that we promised to table legislation before Parliament in December 1988. Certainly I did not create that impression that the Bill was intended to be tabled before December 1988. It could not be possible because we held the election in September 1988, and at that time none of us had decided when the first Parliament Sitting would be held. So nobody in his right mind would have promised to have the Bill tabled in Parliament before December 1988.

    Again, he suggested that somehow we created the impression that the elected President proposal was to be implemented almost immediately. To borrow his words, "imminent". I think he was the one who created this impression in the minds of the public. All we did was to put our necks on the chopping block because this was an important issue. We wanted them to know that when we were returned after the elections we would proceed to implement this constitutional change. Nowhere did

Column: 180

we create the sense of imminence that the proposal was about to be implemented immediately after the elections. It was the Opposition parties who suggested that there was a ploy, that Mr Lee Kuan Yew was meant to be the first candidate for the elected President. In the process, I think they have created this impression in the people's mind that it was something to be held imminently.

    I am a little surprised that Mr Chiam should be wondering why we took such a long time. It is an important piece of legislation and I thought he would welcome the fact that we are letting the matter lie for as long as possible so that he, Members of the Opposition parties and the public, would have as much time as possible to think over this, to chew over this and to digest the proposal before the Bill comes before the House.

    In the last election, town council was an issue but the issue was the elected President and both the Opposition and ourselves joined issue on this. Let us not forget that. We joined issue on this and they went out to campaign that the PAP should be denied two-thirds of the seats so that we could not carry through the proposal. They lost. I think the matter is closed.

    As to consulting the people, that will carry on. The Bill will be presented to the House. It will be fully debated in this House. We will hold feedback sessions with members of the public to explain the intricacies and the main objectives of the Bill. We will send it to a Select Committee so that if there are suggestions for improvements on the Bill, those suggestions will be taken into account by the Government before we pass the Bill in this House.

    I think I have said as much as I could say on this subject. To repeat, we intend to table the Bill before this House sometime this year, and Members will have full opportunity to debate the provisions in the Bill.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Sir, even if denial of the two-thirds of seats to the PAP was campaigned for by one of the Opposition parties, it does not mean that everyone in the Opposition had campaigned for the

Column: 181

same thing. I wish that the Government Ministers do not become infected with the same kiasu syndrome that they themselves have advised other people against. Therefore, if the Government really has confidence of the support of the people, after all it had 60% of popular votes, go ahead! Take courage! Let the people see how good our Government is! And if more people should support the Government on the issue in a referendum, I certainly would acknowledge that the Government has that support. Otherwise, the Government cannot claim that it has got the support.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Sir, I am perplexed by the stand of Dr Lee Siew-Choh. I do not know what rule he is going by to say that the Government does not have the support of the people when it has 60% of the votes, and it has won the election decisively - 80 out of 81 seats. In case he has forgotten, there were 11 uncontested seats, and we claim 100% of those votes. Added together with the seats contested, I think we can come to some conclusions whether we have or do not have more than two-thirds of the popular votes.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Let the Government show that support in a referendum. Let Government show it.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Just one final word. There is no need for us to pursue the subject any further. The decision has been taken by the people, and it is clear as to where the decision lies.

     The Chairman: Mr Chiam, would you like to withdraw your amendment?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $14,674,720 for Head U ordered to stand part of the Main Estimates.

    The sum of $1,519,900 for Head U ordered to stand part of the Development Estimates.

Column: 181



    Head K -

     The Chairman: Head K - Ministry of Defence - Amendment No. (1), 80 minutes. Mr Das.

Column: 182



     Mr S. Chandra Das (Cheng San GRC): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head K of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, in proposing this amendment, I would like to ask the Minister to brief this House on the status of our bilateral and multi-lateral defence relations, especially those with our neighbours. In particular, the GPC on Defence and Foreign Affairs would like to know whether there have been any new initiatives taken last year to enhance cooperation among our neighbours. In addition to the status of relations, we would also be interested to know the nature of cooperation between our SAF and the foreign armed forces.

    Sir, we would also like to know the various exercises that our SAF will be conducting with our neighbours and also to enquire from the Minister whether any scheduled exercise or exercises have been cancelled, and if these have been cancelled, what are the reasons.

     The Chairman: Mr Das, would you like to go on to your next subject - Recognition of Reservists?

     Mr Chandra Das: Sir, maybe we take the subject of Reservists separately.

     The Chairman: All right.

     The Second Minister for Defence (Services) (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Sir, in response to the question from Mr Das, Mindef's policy is to build close defence relations with our neighbours. The more channels of communications we have, the more opportunities of interaction we create, the better we will understand each other, and the less likely we are to harbour unfounded suspicions of each other's motives, or wrong assessments of each other's competence and abilities. Therefore, we hold regular combined exercises and other forms of diplomacy with the Asean countries, with our FPDA partners, and with other friendly countries.

    For example, take Indonesia. In March 1989, we opened the Siabu Air Weapons Range in Sumatra, for a joint Indonesian and Singapore air force training. The RSAF has been using this Range ever since. Our A4s, Skyhawks, F5s, and S211 trainer air-

Column: 183

craft have been deployed to Siabu for a three-week detachments. In work year 1989, six detachments were carried out. This year, another five are planned.

    The Air Force also conducts a regular Joint Weapons Course together with the Indonesians. Both instructors and student pilots on the course come from both Air Forces. The first course was held in June 1988. The second course is currently in progress. It is in two phases. The first, an academic phase, was held in Singapore in February this year. And the second phase, which is a flying phase, will take place in Pekan Baru, using Siabu Range, later this month.

    For the army, Exercise Safkar Indopura was the first combined exercise with Indonesia. It was, a battallion level may planning exercise held in Singapore in December 1989. The next Ex Safkar Indopura is scheduled for December 1990, and will be hosted by Indonesia.

    In view of the successful partnership between the SAF and ABRI, the two Armed Forces are now discussing additional possibilities for broadening their scope of cooperation, especially between the RSAF and TNI-AU.

    With Brunei, we conduct Exercise Pelican - a naval exercise. One is currently in progress at the Tactical Training Centre in Brani Naval Base. A Royal Brunei Armed Forces platoon will be joining an SAF armour battalion live firing exercise this year for the first time. The exercise, condenamed Juggernaut, will be held in April and May this year.

    In Exercise Flaming Arrow, a Brunei infantry company participates in an SAF infantry battalion live firing. The next such Exercise will be held in July and August this year.

    With Malaysia, we carried out land exercises for the first time codenamed Exercise Semangat Bersatu, in May 1989 in Singapore. The second such exercise was held in October 1989 in Sarawak.

    Sir, the Member also asked whether any bilateral exercises have been called off. In fact we had planned to conduct Exercise Malapura, a naval exercise, with Malaysia.

Column: 184

This was to have been an exercise without ships, at the Lumut Tactical Training Centre, between the RSN and the RMN in April. The exercise has been called off at the request of the Malaysians.

     Mr Chandra Das: Sir, thank you very much. I will continue with the subject of Reservists.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Sir, can I seek some clarification before he goes to the next subject?
